 my expert report dated 2 February 2022 (" Nathanael 1 "). Nathanael 1 appended

2. I have been instructed by the solicitors for the Claimant in these proceedings to produce

consider this would assist the court. My evidence appears in sections below under subject

3. Where I do not specifically address a matter raised in the Joint Report and/or in Erotocritou

Subject 1: The Civil law system and framework in Cyprus 
(c) To what extent are common law and equity applicable in Cyprus law? 
4. The jurisdictional basis of all civil law in Cyprus is taken and derives from English legal 
principles and legal concepts as founded and developed by case law. Common law and 
equitable principles are a fundamental part of Cyprus' legal system, they underpin our own 
case law and form an indispensable tool in the unfolding of our legal thinking and way of 
interacting with other legal systems.

5. The Cypriot law of contract and of torts, the core subjects of the civil law of rights and 
obligations, are taken from and are based on the fundamental legal principles developed in 
England in relation to these subjects. By way of example: 
 the manner in which English legal principles come to form part of the law of Cyprus 
can be seen in the area of interim or interlocutory injunctions, a basic tool in civil 
law. Section 32 of the Courts of Justice Law No 32/60 provides in a general way 
that an interim injunction may be issued where (i) there is a serious question to be 
tried, (ii) there is a probability that the applicant is entitled to a remedy, and (iii) that 
unless the interim injunction is issued it will be difficult or impossible for justice to 
be done at a later stage. Section 32 has been the subject of many judgments of the 
Supreme Court of Cyprus (the leading case being Odysseos v Pieris Estates Ltd 
(1982) 1 CLR 557 ) and has been interpreted as being of such a wide ambit so as 
to allow our courts to grant Anton Pillar  Orders, ( In re Ch

 in Stylianou v Papakleovoulou (1982) 1 CLR 542 , the Supreme Court of Cyprus 
reviewed the history of the acceptance of the doctrine of equitable estoppel as part 
of Cypriot law, which it described as having " gained, in recent decades, 
considerable ascendency under the guidance of Lord Denning M.R., as a 
fundamental aspect of English law ", with the further comment being made that " [t]he 
imaginative, if we may say so with respect, application of the doctrine by English 
courts, in diverse circumstances, has broadened the frontiers of justice ". The Court 
then considered whether recent developments to the doctrine in England should be 
followed so as to allow a claimant in Cyprus to invoke estoppel in order to found 
proprietary rights, concluding that they should be followed: 
"Until the decision in Crabb v. Arun. D.C.  [1975] 3 All E.R. 865, it was debatable 
whether promissory estoppel could found a cause of action. The prevalent view was 
that it could be put forward as a shield but not used as a sword for the vindication 
of the rights of the promisee. In Crabb  supra, the Court of Appeal found there is no 
justification for this limitation nor any intrinsic need for thus limiting a fundamental 
doctrine of justice, and pronounced that in appropriate circumstances it could be 
invoked to find property rights; hence proprietary estoppel. …

6. It follows that the existence or formulation of concepts in a given legal text, like that of the 
Cyprus Contract Law, Cap. 149, is not by itself a hindrance to our courts in following and 
accepting English case law in its present form, as the same has over the years developed 
in a particular area. 
7. As regards the disagreement between Mr Erotocritou and myself under this heading, at 
page 3 of the Joint Report, Mr Erotocritou states: " Caselaw from England and other 
common law jurisdictions can be taken into account under Cyprus law to the extent that 
such caselaw is not inconsistent with the express wording of a legislative enactment in 
Cyprus, or the caselaw of the Supreme Court of Cyprus ". This statement reflects paragraph 
5.9.3 of Erotocritou 1.  
8. Whilst I cannot say that anything in the above statement is wholly incorrect, I am unable to 
agree totally with what Mr Erotocritou says for the following reasons. 
9. First, Mr Erotocritou's statement does not adequately reflect the degree to which English 
case law (and that of other common law jurisdictions) is followed in Cyprus. His phrasing, 
that such case law " can be taken into account "

9. First, Mr Erotocritou's statement does not adequately reflect the degree to which English 
case law (and that of other common law jurisdictions) is followed in Cyprus. His phrasing, 
that such case law " can be taken into account " where no specific Cypriot legislation or 
Supreme Court of Cyprus ruling to the contrary exists, understates the position, and 
significantly so. Rather, for judges and practitioners in Cyprus reference to and reliance 
upon English case law is an almost daily affair. English cases are not merely " taken into 
account " in the absence of binding Cypriot law or precedent, they are of great persuasive 
authority. As may be seen from the many English cases that are subsequently referred to 
in this report, English precedents do constantly form the basis of legal reasoning in Cypriot 
judgments.  
10. The difference between Mr Erotocritou and I on this point is, therefore, a question of degree, 
rather than one of fundamental disagreement, but it is an important difference because in 
my view the importance and relevance of English case law to the historic and ongoing 
development of Cypriot law cannot be understated. English principles of common law and 
equity are followed in Cyprus not only in the area of unjust enrichment, by reason of section 
2(1) of the Contract Law, Cap. 149, which states that " expressions used …. shall be 
presumed so far as is consistent with their context, and except as may be otherwise 
expressly provided, to be used with the meaning attaching to them in English law… ", but in 
all areas of the law by reason of section 29(1)(c) of the Court of Justice Law 14/60 
(discussed at paragraphs 14 to 19 of Artemis 2), which reinforces section 2(1) by enshrining 
English principles of common law and equity as a source of law.

11. Secondly, I consider that Mr Erotocritou's statement similarly understates, significantly, the 
degree of contradiction that would have to exist between a legal rule established in English 
case law, on the one hand, and a rule established by Cypriot legislation or a judgment of 
the Supreme Court of Cyprus, on the other, before the English rule would be disregarded. 
Mr Erotocritou suggests that mere inconsistency between the two is enough, but in my 
experience, and as I stated on page 6 of the Joint Report, it is only where there is specific 
Cypriot legislation to the contrary, which can only be interpreted in one way, that the 
application of English case law on the same issue will be precluded. My statement in this 
regard should be understood to apply equally to judgments of the Supreme Court of Cyprus, 
i.e., it is only where there is no room for interpretation of a rule emanating from such a 
judgment that, in my view, the potential application of a rule emanating from English case 
law to the contrary will be excluded. 
12. I consider that my above opinion is well supported by the case law discussed at paragraphs 
19 to 25 of Nathanael 1 and paragraph 21 of Artemis 2 (and which I discuss further at 
paragraphs 45 to 47 below), and the leading academic commentary I quote at paragraphs 
25 and 26 below, which together show that the Cypriot courts have repeatedly approved 
English legal pronouncements on unjust enrichment and incorporated principles of unjust 
enrichment and restitution developed in England when construing section 70 of the Contract 
Law, Cap. 149, in particular.

17. As a second example, I would refer to section 2(2)(d) of the Contract Law, Cap. 149, which 
provides: " When, at the desire of the promisor, the promisee or any other person has done 
or abstained from doing, or does or abstains from doing, or promises to do or to abstain 
from doing something, such act or abstinence or promise is called a consideration for the 
promise " (emphasis added). This statutory provision is generally understood in the Cypriot 
legal community to differ from (and to exclude) traditional English common law rules insofar 
as the underlined language makes clear that: (i) past consideration can support a valid 
contract, and (ii) consideration can move from a third party, rather than the promisee 
(although the third party cannot enforce the contract as he is not a party to it).  
18. As regards past consideration, in Raif v Dervish (1971) 1 CLR 158 , which concerned a

frequently cited in support of the proposition that past consideration is capable of supporting 
a valid contract under Cypriot law. In Romanos v Chrysanthou (1991) 1 CLR 991 , the 
Supreme Court referred to Raif with approval in concluding that the past consideration at 
issue in that case was valid and lawful. In "The Law of Contract at Common Law and in

20. As a third example, I would refer to section 63 of the Contract Law, Cap. 149, which 
provides: " Every promisee may dispense with or remit, wholly or in part, the performance 
of the promise made to him, or may extend the time for such performance, or may accept

31, the Supreme Court considered a case in which the parties entered a contract in 1942

balance within two years, whereupon the property would be transferred. By a series of 
subsequent oral agreements, the parties agreed to extend the date for performance of the 
sale contract, but in 1953 the seller told the purchaser that he had transferred the land to 
his daughter and so could not complete. The purchaser sued, and the seller claimed that 
the action, being on their contract of 1942, was time-barred as the purchaser's cause of

21. Although it is for the legal historian to trace in depth the legal history of Cyprus, it is 
necessary, albeit in summary, to explain a few basic things in order to understand the way 
the Courts in Cyprus interpret, among other legal texts, the Contract Law, Cap. 149.  
22. Before its introduction into the Statute Book in 1931, by the then-British government of 
Cyprus, there were not any systematic rules relating to contracts governing everyday 
transactions on our island. The Ottomans, who ruled Cyprus prior to granting the island to 
the British in 1878, had in place their own law based mainly on the Muslim Sacred Law, but 
in 1867, the then-British Consul in Cyprus made a report stating that the poor administration 
of justice on the island was causing great damage to the country and was a factor inhibiting 
its progress. ( G. M. Pikis: "The English Common Law, the Rules of Equity and their

law rule of Foakes v Beer .

implementation in Cyprus, Chapter 1 ).The British then introduced English law to Cyprus 
in stages, starting with the administration of the Courts (Courts of Justice Order, 1882), and 
they also used the tool of civil procedure in furtherance of the overall administration of 
justice. Common law and equity were introduced as a complete system of law in 1935.  
23. It was generally accepted that the English methodology in the legal sphere worked well, as 
it provided for a more systematic approach than had been experienced under Ottoman rule, 
entrenching in practice basic rights like property and civil rights and relieving the people of 
Cyprus from the perceived arbitrariness of Ottoman law. It was for this reason that it was 
felt that the basic legal rules pertaining to contractual relationships as then applied should 
be formulated into a legal text, that is the Contract Law, Cap.149, in order that a systematic 
and unified approach could be taken to determining matters related to contractual 
transactions whilst continuing to follow principles of English common law. In so doing, the 
British followed the same approach as they had taken in India, where there had been 
introduced The Indian Contract Act of 1872 and The Specific Relief Act of 1877.  
24. The Cypriot legislature, upon Independence in 1960, expressly chose to retain English 
common law and equitable principles by way of the Courts of Justice Law No 14/60. 
Moreover, the Constitution of Cyprus, ratified in 1960, by Article 188 retained all laws 
passed prior to Independence subject to their not being in contradiction to any constitutional 
principle.

legal science in relation to unjust enrichment and restitution have progressed a lot more

"[i]n general terms, despite the different wording of the Cypriot law (that the basic notions 
are part of a statute) … the substantive law, as it emerges from the case law of the Supreme

enrichment as well as restitution issues … Furthermore, it was immaterial that the 
provisions of the Cypriot law appear to form part of the Contract Law or that at the time of 
enacting the Contract Law the basic theory that the English Courts had followed was that 
of an implied or quasi contract. The Cypriot Courts simply follow English case law in 
delineating unjust enrichment in strict terms, as well as in related areas where there seems 
that an obligation is created on the part of one person against another outside of contract. 
Noteworthy is the reference in recent Cypriot case law to the four criteria or questions 
usually asked on unjust enrichment (always in a strict sense), as well as the response of 
the Cypriot Courts to the two related areas regarded as part of the wider notion of unjust 
enrichment, firstly, granting the remedy of restitution in relation to tortious and contractual

where these rights have unlawfully passed on to the ownership or control of another 
(through tracing or constructive trust)" (emphasis added).
27. I agree with Mr Polyviou's analysis. 
28. Against this background, I now turn to consider Mr Erotocritou's statement at paragraph 
2.1, page 5 of the Joint Report, that " [t]he Contract Law, Cap.149, is largely a codification 
of the English common law connected with contracts ". This statement reflects his opinion 
as stated at paragraph 5.4 of Erotocritou 1.  
29. I do not agree. The Contract Law, Cap. 149, does not represent an effort at codification, 
but consolidation: it is expressly stated at the outset, before section 1, that it is a law " [t]o 
amend and consolidate the law relating to contract " (emphasis added). 
30. As to the difference between these terms, according to one legal dictionary, the purpose of 
codification is to " present an orderly and authoritative statement of the leading rules of law 
on a given subject, whether those rules are to be found in statute or common law ", whereas 
the purpose of consolidation is to " present the whole body of the statutory law on a subject 
in complete form, repealing the former statutes ." (Words and Phrases Legally Defined" 
Second Edition, Vol.5. pages 110-111). According to another, Jowitt's Dictionary of 
English Law Second Edition, Volume 1, page 1695-1696,  a statute is consolidating 
"when it consolidates or throws together, into one statute, several previous statutes relating 
to the same subject- matter, with or without alterations of substance ." According to a third,

31. Such definitions are reflected in case law. As stated in Administrator- General of Bengal 
v Prem Lal Mullick (1895) L.R. 22 Ind. App. 107, P.C. per Lord Watson  at p.116, " The 
very object of consolidation is to collect the statutory law bearing upon a particular subject, 
and to bring it down to date, in order that it may form a useful code applicable at the time 
when the consolidating Act is passed "(emphasis added).  
32. Putting it in simple terms, in my view when a legislature looks to consolidate the law in 
relation to a particular subject matter, this means that it seeks to draw together into one 
place, from current disparate sources, rules relating to that subject matter. In comparison, 
when a legislature looks to codify the law in relation to a particular subject matter (a process
